docs.lead_paragraph: LAST year, when my son Sean was 12, he started to shoot baskets, watch too much television and have his first major crush. He said ''my bad'' after forgetting homework and plunged his size-seven feet into sneakers before bolting without a jacket. All of this astonished me -- not because he was growing up, but because he was leaving the land of special needs that he and I had inhabited for such a long time.

headline.main: When a Child Outgrows the Safety Net

docs.abstract: Lisa Romeo Generations essay, adapted from essay in book Special Gifts: Women Writers on the Heartache, Happiness and Hope in raising a Special Needs Child, on signs that her 12-year-old son, Sean, may be outgrowing his developmental problems; drawing (M)

docs.section_name: Health; Books; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: A letter writer (Letters, April 29) wrote to complain about the Ethicist's response to a reader (April 15) who declined to be examined in front of medical students. He said he does his ''fair share'' by paying staggering insurance premiums. How narrow-minded to think that there is an entitlement to have no one in the room, when so many would gladly trade places to get the high quality care that teaching institutions provide. The Ethicist was right.
docs.abstract: Adam Pulver scores Apr 29 letter responding to Randy Cohen Ethicist column of Apr 15 on whether it was appropriate to decline to be examined in front of medical students
